g.title: goal-security
g.text: People using Rust rarely -- if ever -- experience security vulnerabilities or issues
In companies using Rust widely, security engineers are able to refocus their attention on higher-level security issues

g.title: security-response
g.text: When issues do arise with a Rust crate, people know how to report them, and crate authors effectively respond to them
Support program for crate authors who have security issues reported to them
Coordinated disclosure of security issues for Rust

g.title: crates.io-secure
g.text: People can choose crates from crates.io without fear of vulnerabilities or trojans
Authors can publish code in crates on crates.io with confidence that their users will receive the same code
build.rs and procedural macros can be sandboxed

g.title: crates-secure
g.text: Authors of crates on crates.io are able to ensure their own crates security
Crates on crates.io maintain strong security practices

g.title: core-secure
g.text: Security of Rust and Rust crates
Programs written in Rust do not have memory safety issues in practice
People are unable to produce a crash using only safe Rust and the standard library

g.title: safe-rust
g.text: MIR has a formal model that has been proven sound
We have high confidence that Rust's MIR toolchain matches this model
Rearchitect core parts of compiler for clarity, flexibility

g.title: unsafe-rust
g.text: The soundness rules for unsafe code are understood and followed by authors of unsafe Rust code
Tooling to dynamically test soundness of unsafe code is accessible and widely used
Tooling to statically prove soundness of unsafe code is available
Core Rust crates that have soundness proofs
Sanitizers and other dynamic testers for UB
Model checkers and Rust theorem provers

g.title: formal-methods-tooling
g.text: Developers extending Rust with unsafe Rust can prove these extensions correct
Developers can prove their Rust code meets functional specifications
Developers can prove their Rust code meets specification
Sanitizer / dynamic checker for unsafe code

g.title: semi-stable-apis
g.text: Compiler offers semi-stable APIs that others can use
Shared crate for representing Rust types
Access to Rust type information and type check results
Access to the MIR for a given function

g.title: fundamentals
g.text: Easy to contribute to the compiler
Extending language possible by mere humans
